dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so there's this really interesting piece we were looking at today, all about the EU's proposed Digital Services Tax, or DST.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so there's this really interesting piece we were looking at today, all about the E U's proposed Digital Services Tax, or D S T.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A prime example is the European Commissions proposal, first published in March 2018, to create an EU digital services tax (DST).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and you know, on the surface, it sounds like a good idea, right? Like, the UN initially proposed it back in 2018, specifically to go after these huge multinational tech giants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and you know, on the surface, it sounds like a good idea, right? Like, the U N initially proposed it back in twenty eighteen, specifically to go after these huge multinational tech giants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A prime example is the European Commissions proposal, first published in March 2018, to create an EU digital services tax (DST).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the ones that, uh, kind of shuffle their profits around to low-tax jurisdictions. That's the narrative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the ones that, uh, kind of shuffle their profits around to low-tax jurisdictions. That's the narrative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The measure is aimed mainly at multinational tech giants whose corporate structures allow them to siphon digitally-derived profits to low-tax jurisdictions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The idea is to make them pay their fair share where they actually operate. But the article makes a pretty strong case that it wouldn't quite work out that way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The idea is to make them pay their fair share where they actually operate. But the article makes a pretty strong case that it wouldn't quite work out that way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, no. The author, who's the CEO of Booking.com, actually argues that it's Europe's *own* startups and digital ecosystems that would end up paying the biggest price. Which, uh, feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no. The author, who's the C E O of Booking.com, actually argues that it's Europe's own startups and digital ecosystems that would end up paying the biggest price. Which, uh, feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But should the DST take effect, it will be Europes own startups and digital ecosystems that pay the biggest price. ... Gillian Tans is CEO of Booking.com

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It totally does! And the core of it, really, is this outdated idea that digital companies are somehow fundamentally different from traditional businesses. When, you know, everything's becoming digitized.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It totally does! And the core of it, really, is this outdated idea that digital companies are somehow fundamentally different from traditional businesses. When, you know, everything's becoming digitized.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The proposed DST, as well as rushed digital taxation efforts by several EU member states, reflects the outdated idea that digital companies are different from traditional businesses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that distinction is just getting, like, increasingly unsustainable. And the big problem they highlight is taxing based on *revenue* rather than *realized income*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that distinction is just getting, like, increasingly unsustainable. And the big problem they highlight is taxing based on revenue rather than realized income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, taxing businesses based on revenue rather than realized income will result in an intolerably heavier tax burden for enterprises with low profits and high turnover.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is huge! Because if you have high turnover but low *profit margins*, you're suddenly hit with a massive tax burden. It's not targeting Google or Apple; it's hitting smaller, growing tech startups.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is huge! Because if you have high turnover but low profit margins, you're suddenly hit with a massive tax burden. It's not targeting Google or Apple; it's hitting smaller, growing tech startups.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Rather than hitting the targeted tech giants, a DST would most likely be a hindrance to the many European tech startups that have become global leaders in their fields.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's like, uh, designed to hinder the very companies you want to see thrive in Europe. And then there's the other big issue: the patchwork.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's like, uh, designed to hinder the very companies you want to see thrive in Europe. And then there's the other big issue: the patchwork.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The second problem is the likely creation of a patchwork of digital taxation measures, both within and beyond the EU.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the patchwork! That's, um, potentially even worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the patchwork! That's, um, potentially even worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because if the EU does this, other countries are gonna follow suit, and then suddenly you have this mess of conflicting tax rules globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because if the E U does this, other countries are gonna follow suit, and then suddenly you have this mess of conflicting tax rules globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Furthermore, a rushed or ill-considered digital taxation strategy by the EU could result in a template that is replicated internationally. This could lead to a patchy global tax map, with confusion, variation, and forms of double taxation accepted as standard.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Confusion, double taxation, especially for small and medium-sized businesses trying to operate across borders. It just sounds like a nightmare.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Confusion, double taxation, especially for small and medium-sized businesses trying to operate across borders. It just sounds like a nightmare.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This could lead to a patchy global tax map, with confusion, variation, and forms of double taxation accepted as standard. The consequences, in terms of the growth and survival of small and medium-size business around the world, could be grave.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the alternative then? Because obviously, there's a problem with current tax structures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the alternative then? Because obviously, there's a problem with current tax structures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article points to the OECD and G20 efforts. They're actually making good progress towards a consensus on digital taxation that covers, like, search engines and online marketplaces.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article points to the O E C D and G20 efforts. They're actually making good progress towards a consensus on digital taxation that covers, like, search engines and online marketplaces.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On a more encouraging note, the OECD is making good progress toward reaching a consensus on digital taxation covering search engines, online marketplaces, and social media platforms. I strongly believe that collaboration at the OECD/G20 level is essential...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that feels like the right approach, doesn't it? A global, uniform framework based on realized income, not just, uh, gross revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that feels like the right approach, doesn't it? A global, uniform framework based on realized income, not just, uh, gross revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Business taxation must continue to be based fundamentally on realized income, and a global consensus regarding the development of a uniform taxation framework is now essential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Because otherwise, you're just creating more problems than you're solving, especially for the businesses we want to see grow and succeed in Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Because otherwise, you're just creating more problems than you're solving, especially for the businesses we want to see grow and succeed in Europe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a European company, we want to see EU businesses grow, succeed, and become leaders in this exciting new landscape. Separate tax measures, such as the DST, for digital companies are short-sighted and unrealistic, and will ultimately prove counterproductive for all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's about safeguarding growth, particularly when economic conditions are already challenging. This DST seems, like, completely counterproductive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's about safeguarding growth, particularly when economic conditions are already challenging. This D S T seems, like, completely counterproductive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What we want is a fair, supportive corporate tax system to help safeguard growth across the board, particularly when economic conditions are challenging. ... Separate tax measures, such as the DST, for digital companies are short-sighted and unrealistic, and will ultimately prove counterproductive for all.
